title-group.article-title: Dynamic modeling of the Insulin-Glucose-Glucocorticoid impulsive control system

institution-wrap.institution: Natural Science Basic Research Program of Shaanxi Province

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Diabetes is a chronic disease characterized by elevated glycemic levels due to insufficient insulin production or impaired insulin function. This condition has emerged as a significant non-communicable disease that poses serious risks to public health. Diabetes mellitus is categorized into type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) based on its underlying causes1–3. T1DM is an autoimmune disorder in which T-lymphocytes activate the autoimmune system, resulting in the destruction of islet cells and a complete deficiency of endogenous insulin. In contrast, T2DM is characterized by the body’s inability to effectively absorb and metabolize glucose4,5.

To study insulin dynamics and therapeutic strategies, mathematical modeling of clinical data has become a critical tool in disease research9–12,14,15. Existing models have explored dynamic behaviors and elucidated relevant biological mechanisms of diabetes, including compartmental and systemic models based on insulin transport16–18. For instance, Ali et al.19 incorporated the influence of growth hormone in the treatment of diabetic patients by constructing an ordinary differential system, demonstrating the existence of stable equilibria under self-regulated internal environmental adjustments; Huang et al.20 introduced fixed-time and state-dependent impulsive dynamics to study diabetes, employing linear impulsive differential equations to depict transient drug administration, leading to conclusions on stable periodic solutions; Wang et al.13 extended existing linear impulsive systems by utilizing double fixed-time impulses to characterize distinct instantaneous effects, including exogenous insulin administration and food intake; Ma et al.21developed an ordinary differential system that enhanced pharmacokinetic effects by employing the Michaelis-Menten function to simulate endogenous insulin degradation, yielding more practical theoretical results; In 2024, Li et al.22 applied the Michaelis-Menten function to impulsive systems, considering the combined effects of multiple medications on diabetic patients, thereby offering biologically meaningful theoretical guidance for clinical treatments. These studies use mathematical models to analyze the dynamics of diabetes, advancing the understanding of its pathogenesis.

However, existing studies have not comprehensively considered the mechanisms of hormonal interactions within the body, the impacts of exogenous treatments, and the nonlinear processes of pharmacokinetics. Therefore8,19,22–24, based on the aforementioned influence of glucocorticoids in the treatment of diabetic patients and the widespread use of glucocorticoid-like medications, we propose a novel dynamic model incorporating insulin-glucose-glucocorticoid interactions with double fixed-time pulse effects. Additionally, we include the Michaelis-Menten effect with constant secretion to simulate the endogenous dynamics of glucocorticoids. Unlike the Michaelis-Menten function without secretion phenomena, this approach provides a biologically more realistic representation24. In this study, we conducted a qualitative analysis of the proposed model, yielding more realistic results compared to traditional diabetes models. From the perspective of clinical treatment, our aim is to achieve precise glucose control under a combined therapeutic strategy involving glucocorticoids and exogenous insulin. This approach seeks to better mitigate insulin resistance and provide a theoretical foundation for the treatment of diabetes patients.

sec.title: Model formulation
Preliminaries
sec.p: To facilitate the subsequent proofs, we first present some lemmas and definitions:

Definition 1.5

Mathematical analysis and results
Positivity of the system
Theorem 2.1
Proof
Existence of solution of the system
sec.p: We have established that the solutions of system (1) maintain positivity, which is consistent with the biological significance assumed by the system. To discuss the dynamical behavior of system (1), we will next provide a proof of the existence of solutions.

sec.title: Theorem 2.2
Proof
Stability of the system
sec.p: The use of insulin and glucocorticoids carry the risk of inducing insulin resistance or causing side effects. One of the goals of diabetes treatment is to regulate a patient’s glucose levels within a reasonable range through the periodic use of insulin or other medications. If the periodic solution is stable, by determining the injection interval and the dosage of exogenous agents, the patient’s glucose level will approach a stable periodic state over time. Even when subjected to small disturbances or fluctuations, it will not deviate from the normal range. This is crucial for maintaining long-term glucose control in diabetes treatment. Therefore, the following section provides the stability results of the model:

sec.title: Theorem 2.3
Proof
Permanent system
sec.p: To ensure optimal long-term glucose control in T2DM, it is crucial o maintain glucose levels within stable range, avoiding extreme fluctuations. Therefore, this paper investigates the persistence of the T2DM model during the design regimes of exogenous insulin injection and glucocorticoids, aiming to avoid episodes of hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia.

sec.title: Theorem 2.4
Proof
Numerical simulations

tr.td: Glucose−dependent on islet β cell secretion coefficient
Glucose clearance rate independent o f insulin
Rates o f insulin−induced glucose uptake reactions
Rate o f hepatic glucose production
Glucocorticoid−induced insulin resistance glucose increase ratio coefficient
Rates o f glucocorticoid secretion in the zona f asciculata o f the adrenal cortex
Maximal rate o f glucocorticoid degradation

sec.p: Based on the above proofs, we have established the positivity, existence, and stability of periodic solutions for the T1DM model, as well as the persistence of the T2DM model. With fixed parameters (as shown in Table 1), these results can be validated through numerical simulations. Furthermore, by comparing different scenarios, we highlight the necessity of considering glucocorticoids in diabetes treatment strategies to understand their impact.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Compared to other research, such as the work of Smith et al.27, which primarily focused on the insulin response dynamics without incorporating glucocorticoid interactions, our model addresses the broader physiological interplay between insulin and glucocorticoids, providing a more comprehensive approach to managing glucose levels in diabetic patients. Furthermore, the study by Jones et al.28 analyzed insulin administration’s effects on glucose but did not consider the complications arising from glucocorticoid treatment. In contrast, our model shows that the co-administration of insulin and glucocorticoids, especially in Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), can offer better control over glucose levels if carefully managed.

Based on this study, it can be concluded that the combined treatment strategy of glucocorticoid and insulin is feasible at a reasonable drug concentration in T1DM patients. It can avoid glucocorticoid-induced insulin resistance and control the metabolic disorders of organs and tissues affected by insulin resistance (such as liver and skeletal muscle). The present study yields practical guiding significance for clinical treatment. However, for the current study, introducing fractional-order derivatives and their properties could further enhance the modeling of the diabetes system. By using fractional-order derivatives to characterize the memory characteristic of biological systems, we can gain a deeper understanding of the pathogenesis, leading to more accurate treatment strategies. Such as Hattaf29who introduced a novel mixed fractional derivative and examines its applications in computational biology. The proposed mixed fractional derivative integrates both fractional and integer-order derivatives, offering a new approach for modeling complex biological systems. And presentd a new class of generalized fractal and fractal-fractional derivatives characterized by non-singular kernels. The authors introduce and analyze these derivatives, extending the concept of traditional fractional calculus to include fractal and mixed fractal-fractional orders30. The study focuses on the theoretical foundation of these new derivatives, mathematical properties, and potential applications in modeling complex systems where traditional fractional derivatives may fall short. Additionally, external injections and other impulsive terms need not be limited to constant linear pulses, they could be extended to nonlinear pulses to achieve more optimal results.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Y.L and C.L wrote the main manuscript text, and conducted mathematical analyses. X.F contributed to numerical simulations and funding acquisition. T.D improved the manuscript’s language. The final version of the submission was agreed upon by all authors.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was partially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 12326417, 62102304); National Foreign Expert Program (No. G2023041033L); The Natural Science Basic Research Plan in Shaanxi Province of China (No. 2023JCYB258, 2023YBGY-016, 2023WGZIZD08); Shaanxi Province Foreign Expert Project (2024WZ-YBXM-01).

notes.p: Data is provided within the manuscript information files.

notes.title: Conflicts of interest
notes.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interests regarding the publication of this paper.
